subj-group.subject: Feature Topic: Advances in Research Methods From Outside the Organizational Sciences

title-group.article-title: Modeling the Mind and the Milieu
title-group.subtitle: Computational Modeling for Micro-Level Organizational Researchers

bio.title: Bios
bio.p: Jeffrey B. Vancouver is a professor of Industrial and Organizational psychology at Ohio University. He is director of HEIDi (Human-Environment Interaction Dynamics initiative), which is an interdisciplinary group of electrical engineers, computer scientists, psychologists, mathematicians, and philosophers. Much of his work involves using complex protocols that generate time series data to assess dynamic computational models of a person interacting with the environment based on a self-regulation perspective.

Justin M. Weinhardt is a PhD candidate in Industrial/Organizational Psychology at Ohio University. His research interests include computational modeling, psychometrics, motivation, decision making, and moral psychology. He has published in Journal of Applied Psychology, Organizational Psychology Review, and Organizational Research Methods.

article-meta.aff: 1Department of Psychology, Ohio University, Athens, OH, USA

author-notes.corresp: Jeffrey B. Vancouver, Department of Psychology, Ohio University, 221 Porter Hall, Richland Ave, Athens OH 45701, USA Email: vancouve@ohio.edu

abstract.p: Theorists in management and organizational science rarely use computational modeling to support theoretical development or refinement, particularly at the micro level of analysis. This article argues that organizational scholars, who strive to understand dynamic behavior in a complex context, are particularly in need of the support computational models offer. Moreover, organizational scholars can build on (a) the plethora of informal theories extant in the literature and (b) the computational architectures and model building platforms developed in recent years. To increase the number of organizational scholars building and evaluating computational models, the article provides a tutorial in model building and simulation. Specifically, a new computational model is built and assessed. Surprising realizations emerge in the process. There is also an extensive section on model evaluation involving empirical observations.

disp-quote.p: Mathematics is the language with which God has written the universe.

body.p: The opening quote has often been shortened to the maxim that mathematics is the language of science. This maxim is certainly taken seriously in the physical sciences, but it has been taken less seriously in the social sciences (Adner, Pólos, Ryall, & Sorenson, 2009; Harrison, Lin, Carroll, & Carley, 2007). Some might argue that this apathy is because social or psychological phenomena cannot be reduced to mathematical representations. On some level, that sentiment might be true; mathematical models that attempt to describe complex, nonlinear systems interacting dynamically are often intractable (i.e., they cannot be solved). Humans and organizations are frequently recognized as just these types of systems (e.g., Hulin & Ilgen, 2000). Fortunately, a different type of formal modeling—computational modeling—can provide scholars with formal representations of their complex, dynamic theories (Boden, 2008). Computational models are algorithmic descriptions of process details (Sun, 2008), typically operationalized as computer programs (Taber & Timpone, 1996). As such, they provide a more precise, transparent, and internally consistent approach to theorizing (Adner et al., 2009). In particular, we contend that computational modeling is to theories as statistical analysis is to data; that is, it is a tool useful to support inferences when the predicates (i.e., theory/data) are particularly complex.

Despite the positive sentiments expressed regarding computational models, the presence of such models is rare across the subdisciplines in organizational science (Scandura & Williams, 2000). For example, a recent count by Harrison et al. (2007) found that between 1994 and 2003, the Academy of Management Journal published only two articles (0.3%) that included computational models. They found that Administrative Science Quarterly was only slightly better, with 2.2% of its articles computational. We reviewed the Academy of Management Review, the field’s premiere theory journal, from 2000 through 2011. We found no computational models until a special issue on formal models (Volume 34, Issue 2), in which four computational models were presented, followed by one more a couple issues later (1.3% of articles over an 11-year period). The dearth of computational models is even more profound in the micro-level subdiscipline of organizational science. Specifically, none of the aforementioned computational models involved micro-level phenomena (e.g., models of individual-level psychological processes). Moreover, an examination of the top micro-level journal in organizational research, Journal of Applied Psychology, revealed only one computational model published in that journal ever (Vancouver, Weinhardt, & Schmidt, 2010).

Unfortunately, we argue that this relative absence of computational modeling has undermined the quality of theory in the organizational sciences. In particular, organizational scholars often develop verbal dynamic theories, but there is little discussion of how the dynamic relationships play out over time. Moreover, there is a growing body of research showing that even well-educated individuals are poor at understanding the effects of dynamic processes without external aids (e.g., Cronin, Gonzalez, & Sterman, 2009; Hintzman, 1990). In contrast, computational models force scholars to operationalize the underlying assumptions of their theories (Lewandowsky & Farrell, 2011). This can highlight unrecognized problems or advance understanding. In addition, computational models give one the ability to easily test assumptions and assess the robustness of theories. They can also increase the diagnostic value of research by providing clear predictions of dynamic patterns of data or relationships among observable variables while providing plausible explanations for the processes that give rise to the patterns and relationships.

In the following, we elaborate on the advantages of computational models, but the more compelling question is why computational models are so rare in the organizational sciences. We suspect the most likely reason is the absence of modelers. More specifically, we believe that so few organizational scholars produce computational models, particularly at the micro level, because they lack training. We begin to address this issue with this article. We intend to show that learning to create computational models is relatively easy by showing the reader how to build one as well as how to evaluate them. Of course, all good training begins with a clear description of the learning objective and a motivational appeal. We begin there.

sec.title: What Is Computational Modeling, and Why Is It Important?
sec.p: Computational modeling is both a form of, and tool for, theorizing, where theory is an explanation of something (Dubin, 1976; Sutton & Staw, 1995). Adner et al. (2009) divide those explanations into two kinds: formal and informal. They further divide formal theories into three flavors: analytic, simulations, and formal logic (Adner et al., 2009). Analytic theories, also called mathematical models (Sun, 2008), are mathematical statements that can be proven and solved (i.e., are tractable; closed form), leading to specific predictions. In contrast, computational models are computer programs that can be run (i.e., simulated) and where predictions arise from the simulations, not from solving equations. Indeed, simulation is often used as a label for computational models (e.g., Adner et al., 2009; Harrison et al., 2007). We use the term computational models to describe the algorithms (i.e., computer programs) of processes (i.e., the theoretician’s explanation) that can be simulated (i.e., run). That is, a simulation is a run of the model using a given set or distribution of parameters; it is not the model per se.

In contrast to formal theory, informal theory is theory presented in natural language. Because of this, informal theories are also referred to as verbal-conceptual (Sun, 2008), verbal, or “word” theories (Hulin & Ilgen, 2000), though path diagrams or other graphic representations (e.g., grids) depicting the relationship between constructs are a common method of communicating aspects of informal theory (e.g., the implications of the theory in terms of relationships between observable constructs). As noted earlier, nearly all recent theories presented in organizational science are informal, probably due to the richness of natural language and the fact that it is our default mode of communication.

sec.title: Limitations of Verbal Theory
sec.p: Unfortunately, informal theorizing is vulnerable to two limitations: the ambiguity of natural language and the capacity of the human mind, which undermines reasoning and shared understanding (Adner et al., 2009; Farrell & Lewandowsky, 2010; Johnson-Laird & Yang, 2008). In particular, a great deal of research has shown that individuals, even those well educated in STEM fields, have difficulty predicting dynamic processes without the aid of computational supports (e.g., Atkins, Wood, & Rutgers, 2002; Hintzman, 1990; Jensen & Brehmer, 2003; Johnson-Laird & Yang, 2008; Kleinmuntz, 1990; Sweeney & Sterman, 2007).

Consider the following example of a dynamic problem about the number of people in a store, which was examined in a set of studies by Cronin et al. (2009). In one of their studies, 173 participants were given information about the number of people entering a store (inflow) each minute as well as the number of people leaving the store (outflow) each minute over a 30-minute interval. The participants were then asked four questions: (a) During what minute did most people enter the store, (b) during which minute did the most people leave, (c) during which minute were most people in the store, and (c) during which minute were the fewest number of people in the store? What the researchers found was that almost all individuals were able to answer the first (96%) and second (95%) questions correctly, indicating they understood the information presented. However, fewer than half of the individuals were able to answer the third (44%) or fourth (31%) questions correctly. Perhaps what is most surprising about these results is that the participants were MIT Sloan School of Management graduate students. Moreover, all students had taken calculus, a majority (71%) had a STEM degree, and 40% had a prior graduate degree.

Cronin et al. (2009) labeled the inability of individuals to answer the dynamic questions stock-flow (SF) failure. What seem to cause particular problems are dynamic variables. Dynamic variables behave as if they have memory; that is, their value at any one time depends somewhat on their previous value. Common examples of dynamic variables are stocks (e.g., products in inventory, fish in a fishery, or stock market prices) or levels (e.g., the water level in a lake). In all these cases, the variable moves from one state to the next as a function of the inflows and outflows, rather than simply taking on a new value. All dynamic phenomena include dynamic variables (Forrester, 1968).

sec.title: The Relevance of Dynamics
sec.p: Of course, organizational science is replete with dynamic phenomena and process theories (Katzell, 1994). For instance, at the micro level, noncomputational theories of escalating human behavior (e.g., L. M. Andersson & Pearson, 1999; Lindsley, Brass, & Thomas, 1995) and dynamic work motivational processes (e.g., Fried & Slowik, 2004; Kanfer & Ackerman, 2004; Seo, Barrett, & Bartunek, 2004) abound. Moreover, longitudinal empirical work examining dynamic predictions is becoming increasingly more common (e.g., Becker & Cropanzano, 2011; Colquitt, LePine, Piccolo, Zapata, & Rich, 2012; Ilies, Wilson, & Wagner, 2009; Kammeyer-Mueller, Wanberg, Glomb, & Ahlburg, 2005), and several scholars advocate more attention be given to dynamics (Mitchell & James, 2001; Vancouver, 2005). Yet, this theory and research often occur without the benefit of computational models to support the predictions made and tested, sometimes leading to a line of research that is not diagnostic regarding theory.

As an example of this later point, Vancouver, Tamanini, and Yoder (2010) examined the dynamic process of newcomer socialization in an organization. Via computational models, Vancouver, Tamanini, et al. described the received theory of the process that motivates proactive newcomer socialization and used it to reconcile disparate findings from a number of researchers on the topic. Specifically, some researchers find a negative relationship between information seeking and role clarity, but most find a positive relationship (see meta-analysis by Bauer, Bodner, Erdogan, Truxillo, & Tucker, 2007). Yet, the theory predicts that because the amount of seeking of information drops as a function of the seeking (i.e., a dynamic, negative feedback loop), the relationship between seeking and role clarity should be negative. However, the computational model revealed that the sign of the relationship would be a function of design, measurement, and analysis decisions of the researchers; decisions that had typical favor finding a positive effect. Moreover, Vancouver, Tamanini, et al. also modeled a rival theory and demonstrated that current designs were inadequate for distinguishing the theories. This example highlights that dynamic relationships are often difficult to predict, understand, and test without the aid of computational models.

sec.title: Advantages of Computational Models
sec.p: The previous example shows that computational modeling is a useful resource to aid in understanding systems with dynamic variables and in facilitating prediction regarding the behavior of these types of systems. Specifically, a working computational model assures that a theory (a) is internally consistent, (b) accounts for the phenomena claimed, (c) is sufficiently specified, and (d) is unambiguous (Adner et al., 2009; Davis, Eisenhardt, & Bingham, 2007; Farrell & Lewandowsky, 2010; Harrison et al., 2007). For example, computational models require theorists to be complete in their reasoning. Otherwise, the models will not run. In addition, because computational models are precise and unambiguous, they can be disconfirmed more easily. This is important because working models are not necessarily valid. Because of this we devote a large section of this article to methods for evaluating models. Finally, and perhaps most importantly, computational models aid communication by making clear the logic a theorist is using to represent the theory. This is also one of the major reasons it behooves scholars to have a working understanding of computational models. If mathematics is the language of science, and computational models are an expression of that language, scientists should be at least familiar with it. We believe that the best way to do this is to use the language. In this way, one is more likely to not only benefit from its strengths but also to be cognizant of its limitations.

sec.title: Developing of a Computational Model: A Tutorial
sec.p: In this section, we describe the steps necessary to construct and test a computational model beginning with the identification of a problem and ending with how to evaluate computationally rendered dynamic theory.

sec.title: Step 1: Identify a Problem
sec.p: All research projects begin with the identification of a problem (McGrath, Martin, & Kulka, 1982). Problems involving the understanding of dynamic processes are particularly amenable to, and likely to benefit from, computational modeling. Although in some cases this might require new theory development, for which computational modeling can be particularly useful (Davis et al., 2007; Whicker & Sigelman, 1991), it can often involve theory refinement (Edwards, 2010). Therefore, we argue that beginning from an existing theory that describes dynamic phenomenon is a good starting point. This is consistent with a book on cognitive modeling by Busemeyer and Diederich (2010) that states “the first step is to take a conceptual theoretical framework and reformulate its assumptions into a more rigorous mathematical or computer language description” (pp. 5-6).

In addition to starting from existing verbal theory, we also advocate using an existing computational architecture. Computational architectures are meta-theory, grand scope frameworks, or approaches that can be used as a basis for modeling (Taatgen & Anderson, 2008). At the macro and meso levels of analysis of organizational phenomena, computational architectures include system dynamics (e.g., Forrester, 1968; Sastry, 1997) and evolution-inspired (e.g., Bruderer & Singh, 1996; Rivkin, 2001), agent-based (Bonabeau, 2002), and dynamical systems (Schöner, 2008). At the micro level, computational architectures include neural networks (also called connectionist or parallel distributed processing; Lord, Hanges, & Godfrey, 2003; Rumelhart, McClelland, & the PDP Research Group, 1986), production systems (e.g., ACT; J. R. Anderson, 1983; SOAR; Newell, 1990; GPS; Newell & Simon, 1963), and control theory or cybernetics (Powers, 1973; Vancouver, Weinhardt, et al., 2010). These architectures are not mutually exclusive, nor do they need to be restricted to the levels noted previously. For example, dynamical systems and cybernetic models can be found in all the levels relevant for organizational scholars (Richardson, 1991; Vancouver, 1996). Moreover, elements of these architectures (especially from cybernetic/control theory, system dynamics, and production systems) have found their way into informal theorizing. These realities substantially simplify the translation process.

An important point regarding problem definition is that computational models are generally relatively narrow compared to verbal theories and computational architectures. Highlighting that most models are relatively narrow—focusing on one problem or phenomenon—is important for three reasons. First, it helps clarify what is meant by a theoretical contribution (Edwards, 2010). That is, new meta-theories and architectures are nice, but they are rare. Instead, refining and integrating the theories we have could and should be a large part of what a theoretical contribution is all about (Edwards & Berry, 2010). Second, it provides for a challenging, but obtainable goal for the modeler. Finally, it facilitates communication of the theory/model to a community relatively unfamiliar with computational models (Repenning, 2003).

Given the lack of micro-level models, we wanted to provide an example on how to build a computational model of individual-level behavior and psychological process. Yet, we also wanted to use a computational architecture that is likely to be applicable to a large set of organizational phenomena. As mentioned previously, system dynamics (Forrester, 1968) is a popular approach to modeling macro-level phenomenon, but it can also be used to model phenomena using a cybernetic architecture (e.g., Vancouver, Tamanini, et al., 2010; Vancouver, Weinhardt, et al., 2010), which is used to account for dynamic homeostasis, a common phenomenon across many domains and levels of analysis (Vancouver, 1996). For example, dynamic homeostasis is used to describe thirst, hunger, and body temperature control processes as well as goal striving (e.g., striving to bring a perception in line with a goal) and communication processes (e.g., role clarifying episodes; Vancouver, 1996, 2005). Finally, we wanted to consider a relatively simple issue, but one that might have relatively broad implications and benefit. Specifically, theoretical models of job attitudes and stress, which are remarkably similar, could possibly benefit from formal modeling. That is, Edwards (1992) and Hulin and Judge (2003) discuss various theories of both job attitudes and stress using path diagrams often with feedback loops, but these models are not formal. This raises a question regarding the viability of these theories. Therefore, we believe this area would greatly benefit from computational modeling and would also be of interest to many readers.

sec.title: Step 2: System Definition
sec.p: In his text on simulations, Shannon (1975) described the next stage of simulation as system definition. This includes identifying the unit (or units) of analysis, the boundary of the problem to be simulated, the restrictions (e.g., time bounds), and variables. To a large extent, the theory one chooses in the previous step determines these issues. For instance, the theories are psychological, thus the individual is the unit of analysis. However, the question of how much of some theory (or theories) to include in a modeling project can be difficult to determine a priori. As mentioned, models are nearly always narrow relative to the theories and architectures from which they are derived; but how narrow? On this point we agree with the advice of Whicker and Sigelman (1991) that one should begin with as simple a model as one can, make sure it works as intended, and then elaborate upon it, but not too much lest readers are overwhelmed (Repenning, 2003).

We also like our models to be comprehensive in order to be more broadly applicable (Dubin, 1976). In some cases this can be accomplished by looking for reoccurring dynamics across theories. Indeed, Farrell and Lewandowsky (2010) include aiding a science in seeing the underlying structures common among different analogies or phenomena as one of the benefits of computational models. In the example we picked, six theories of stress (for review, see Edwards, 1992) and four theories of attitudes (for review, see Hulin & Judge, 2003) highlight seven variables that kept reappearing, though often using different terms. These variables are listed in Table 1. Moreover, the theories also included a structure that described how these variables influenced each other (e.g., see Figure 1, which is a partial reproduction of Edwards, 1992, model). Specifically, perceptions (1) refer to (i.e., are a function of) environmental states (called “physical and social environment” in Edwards, 1992, model) (2), which are a function of actions or coping (3), which are a function of discrepancies (4), which refer to the difference between desires (5) and perceptions (1). Moreover, the discrepancies (4) affect well-being or, when considering job attitude models, job satisfaction (6), depending on the importance (7) of the discrepancy. This, then, becomes our initial list of variables.

caption.p: Modified version of Edwards’s (1992) cybernetic model of stress, coping, and well-being in organizations

sec.p: The time scale and boundary are perhaps the most difficult elements to determine from the theory one chooses to model because so few of our theories are very specific on this issue (Mitchell & James, 2001). Moreover, we have very little empirical work that addresses rates of change (Ployhart & Vandenberg, 2010). Although this can be problematic because a lack of understanding regarding the rates of change are a major source of error in prediction (Cronin et al., 2009), it is often initially sufficient to know that dynamic variables take time to change (Vancouver, Weinhardt, et al., 2010). Precision regarding the rate of change can come later. Indeed, one aspect of model evaluation will be to assess the importance of varying rates of change, which will determine the usefulness of empirical work focused on assessing such rates (e.g., learning curves). For now, then, we will assume that we are interested in day-to-day change.

sec.title: Step 3: Building the Model
sec.p: Once the variables, or at least a preliminary list of them, have been identified, it is time to begin building the model. Software platforms for building computational models are of two kinds: general and specialized. General platforms include programming languages like C++ or Python, mathematical software like Matlab or Mathematica, or spreadsheet software like Excel (e.g., Latané, 2000). These general platforms can be very flexible, but difficult to learn or use relative to the specialized software. The specialized software, which is growing in kind and flexibility, simplifies much of the modeling processes, including building, evaluating, disseminating, and illustrating the models. A downside is that each is often focused on only one type of modeling approach (e.g., SWARM is a common platform for agent-based models); though, truth be told, so will most modelers.

For our tutorial, we suggest using a system dynamics software platform like Vensim®. Vensim® is a set of user-friendly, highly sophisticated software packages devoted to computational model building. With it one can build a model visually, add math, and then run a simulation. If the simulation is run in interactive mode, graphs appear for each of the time-varying variables and sliders appear for each of the constants/parameters. One can then change the constants/parameters to see immediately the effects of the changes on the behavior of the model. Vensim® has been used to model everything from macro-level phenomenon such as population growth (Meadows, Randers, & Meadows, 2004) or supply chain management (Sterman, 2000) to micro-level phenomenon such as individual multiple-goal pursuit (Vancouver, Weinhardt, et al., 2010). Moreover, a version of Vensim® called VensimPLE®
1 is free for academic and noncommercial use and can be downloaded at www.Vensim.com. To gain the most from this tutorial, we strongly suggest that you download this software and build the model as we describe it in the following. Then you can learn by doing. To facilitate that, we provided a detailed, step-by-step procedure for building and assessing the model using VensimPLE® at the first author’s website (www.ohioupsychology.com/Research-Lab-Index.html?lab=22). It parallels the material presented in the following, but it presents information about the specific software (e.g., interface and features). We also provide a Matlab version of the model (using the control systems toolbox) at the website.

sec.title: Visual depiction by adding variables and arrows
sec.p: Computational models, like informal theories and structural equation models, are often depicted graphically. That is, the variable/construct labels are displayed and directional links between them are drawn. For instance, Figure 1 is part of Edwards’s (1992) model of stress. In informal models like Edwards’s, the directional links indicate the flow of causation or, where arrows point at other arrows, moderation (e.g., importance moderates the relationship between discrepancy and well-being; Figure 1). The convention for system dynamics models, the type of computational model we are building here, is very similar except that the variable labels receiving arrows are also functions. Moreover, the model is dynamic, which means the functions change the variables over time based on the input to those functions. Those variables not receiving arrows are generally constants or parameters, but more generally called exogenous variables, whereas those receiving arrows are called endogenous variables (see Table 1).

Typically, the label used for the function, in the case of endogenous variables, refers to the result of the function. The arrows pointing at a function determine the variables, constants, and coefficients that are in the expression in the function. In this way, the arrows do not always represent what one might typically understand as causality because they might represent a constant or a coefficient that moderates the effect of a variable. However, before we get to pointing variables at each other, the first step is to place variables and constants in the software’s work space or “build window,” similar to how AMOS builds structural equation models. For those playing along at home, now is the time to add the variables listed in Table 1, as well as “bias” and “environmental responsiveness,” which are both exogenous variables. Pay attention to the capitalization used in the table and mimic that.

The next step is to arrange the variables and add arrows. Figure 1 from Edwards (1992) presents a typical arrangement for a cybernetic model except that moderators like “importance” are coefficients for the variables they moderate. Because of this, the moderators need to point at the functions in which they will be used (e.g., well-being and coping). Thus, our model, shown in Figure 2, looks slightly different. We also only surround our endogenous variables with boxes to make the distinction from exogenous variables more clear.

caption.p: Graphic depiction of basic computational model

sec.title: Describing the relationships by adding math
sec.p: The next step in building a model is to describe the relationships among the variables, constants, and coefficients. System dynamics is a quantitative modeling approach, which means the descriptions of the relationships are mathematical. System dynamics software not only provides a place to enter these mathematical descriptions, but makes them functional. That is, the mathematics entered will be used to transform data during a simulation of the model.

In the case of the exogenous variables, we merely need to enter numbers to represent these constants/parameters. Beginning with desires, which will serve as a reference point, we let the natural origin (0) represent the desired level. Next is importance, which according to theories of stress and attitudes (Edwards, 1992) should be a coefficient (i.e., weight). Using 1 for coefficients will keep the terms that use it in their simplest form (i.e., unit weighting). The next exogenous variable, environment responsiveness, will represent the rate at which actions/coping behaviors will have their impact. Using 1 would represent instantaneous effects, which is generally unrealistic. Instead, a fraction should be used to represent the lag in the effect of actions on Environmental States. We chose 0.1 for now. For bias enter 0.

The remaining variables are endogenous, which means they are functions of other variables in the model. The first function we consider is perceptions. Environmental States and bias are the variables that affect perceptions. Specifically, we might use the following function to determine perceptions:

This function means that perception will be a direct function of Environmental States, but with the potential for a bias to represent an individual difference construct indexing how objective states of the environment are biased by an individual’s perspective. Notice that by adding bias to Environmental States to create perceptions, the modeler is assuming that the biasing factor is uniform across levels of Environmental States. A multiplicative function would mean that biasing is conceived of as being more extreme as states moves away from the desired states because we used zero to represent the desires. Moreover, we could simply not have included it here, allowing differences in desires to represent this source of individual difference. However, these possibilities represent different conceptualizations of the underlying structure and processes and can have different empirical implications. For example, by placing bias as a term affecting perceptions, we are explicitly stating (mathematically) that different individuals might distort the objectively same level of state to a different degree that might be reflected in self-report measures of the perceptions of environmental states. Individuals may also differ regarding the desired levels for those states, which our current model can handle because desires is an individual difference parameter in our model. These kinds of issues represent the kind of “ad hoc assumptions” Busemeyer and Diederich (2010) noted that modelers must add to conceptual models while translating them from informal to formal models. Though to be fair, these issues were talked about somewhat in Edwards (1992) and Hulin and Judge (2003).

Next, we consider the discrepancies equation. In control systems vocabulary, this is called the comparator function. Indeed, Hulin and Judge (2003) used the label comparator where Edwards (1992) used the label discrepancies. That is because Hulin and Judge are using the label of the function and Edwards is using the label of the result. Using the label of the result of the function is helpful when model building because the next equation that uses that result will have that label for its expression. It is also consistent with informal path models. Figures representing control theory models seem to be the major exception to this general rule (e.g., Carver & Scheier, 1998).

Regardless of the label, conceptualizing discrepancies as simply the difference between desires and perceptions is not consistent with many conceptualizations of the control systems (Vancouver, 2008). Edwards (1992), for instance, points out that the function will depend on the nature of the desire involved. Some desires are optima, where both positive and negative discrepancies are unwanted. An absolute value function would accomplish that representation. However, most desires are probably maxima, where perceptions of a state (e.g., 10 widgets made) that are less than the desire for the state (i.e., 20 widgets) are what create tension and motivate one to act or be unhappy. In these cases, subtracting perceptions from desires will give a positive number when perceptions are less than desires. This positive number represents a degree of tension (Lewin, 1951), which seems reasonable. However, in the case where perceptions of the state exceed the desired state, we have to make a further distinction for maxima desires. That is, a hard maximum is one where any perception above the desired level creates no discrepancy (see Vancouver, Putka, & Scherbaum, 2005). Alternatively, a soft maximum is one where perceptions exceeding desires could positively affect well-being. A simple way to represent that is to create a conditional for the discrepancy equation based on the sign of the discrepancy. What we want is for positive differences to be passed on and for negative differences to be passed on but dampened. Given decision-making literature that suggests that gains are half as motivating as losses (Tversky & Kahneman, 1992), we can divide the negative discrepancies, which are essentially gains, by 2. This is achieved via the following equation:

Next is well-being, which is presumably related to discrepancies. More specifically, when perceptions are less than desires, well-being should drop, but when they are greater than desires, it should rise (Edwards, 1992). Discrepancies are presumed to have a similar effect on job satisfaction (Hulin & Judge, 2003). That is, Well-Being/Job Satisfaction should be negatively related to discrepancies. Moreover, several models of human behavior suggest that importance is a moderator (or weight) for discrepancies (e.g., Edwards, 1992; Hyland, 1988). Adding importance as a coefficient accomplishes this such that the equation looks like the following:

There is a problem with this equation though. In particular, Well-Being/Job Satisfaction is probably best conceived of as a dynamic variable. This is why we capitalized it—to set it apart. Recall, dynamic variables have memory in that they change their level depending on inflows and outflows. Said another way, one would expect the level of well-being to remain essentially constant, not zero, if perceptions equaled desires. In addition, we would expect well-being to drop if perceptions are less than desires and to rise if perceptions exceed desires. However, for that to happen in our model, we need the equation just created to determine the direction and rate of change in this construct over time. For discrete computational models, the following equation represents Well-Being/Job Satisfaction as a dynamic variable:

As one can see, this equation represents the idea that change in Well-Being/Job Satisfaction from one time (t – 1) to the next (t) is a function of the discrepancy × importance term. Alternatively, if modeling time continuously, which is how it is done in system dynamics models, the following equation could be used:

For most intents and purposes, these two equations represent the same thing, though the differential equation is more general. In either case, some initial value for Well-Being/Job Satisfaction needs to be specified. If we think of well-being or job satisfaction as being on a 10-point scale, we might assume a value of 7 might represent a reasonable starting level for someone.

Next we consider actions/coping behaviors. To be consistent with Edwards (1992), we pointed discrepancies and importance at this variable because the idea is that one acts on, or copes with, discrepancies from important desires. Indeed, this is a central tenet of control theories of human behavior (e.g., Carver & Scheier, 1998; Powers, 1973). Specifically, the degree of action is typically conceived of as a multiplicative function of discrepancy and importance in these models (Hyland, 1988). Therefore, importance is once again a multiplicative factor. Consider, however, that individuals are not likely to behaviorally respond to changes in the sign of the discrepancies as they might respond affectively. That is, we decided to represent soft maxima desires, where perceptions beyond the desired state are a good thing that can increase well-being and job satisfaction, though not to the degree to which perceptions below the desired state decrease well-being and job satisfaction. This was represented mathematically by subtracting importance weighted discrepancies (halved when negative) from the level of well-being, which raises well-being when the discrepancies are negative. However, in the case of actions, one wants to act on positive discrepancies (i.e., when perceptions are below desires) in a positive way (i.e., by trying to make positive changes to the environment). Thus, in this function we do not want to subtract weighted discrepancies, but add them. Thus, the equation could be “discrepancy × importance” like in Well-Being, but without the negative sign. Yet, that is not right either because it means that the individual will act to erase changes to the Environmental States if they rise above one’s desires (i.e., negative discrepancies will be translated to acts that negatively affect Environmental States). This seems problematic.

To rectify this problem we need to return to the equation within the discrepancies variable and move the conditional into the Well-Being and action equations to create a defendable model. Specifically, return to discrepancies and remove all but “desires – perceptions” from the equation. For the Well-Being/Job Satisfaction variable, replace discrepancies with a conditional that passes on positive discrepancies and half the value of negative discrepancies. This conditional result is still multiplied by – 1 and importance and is still the expression within the integral function. Finally, for actions/coping behaviors use the following equation:
Using this equation, positive discrepancies result in positive actions on the environment states, but so do negative discrepancies, though with half the vigor.

Perhaps some of you are on to us already. That is, it seems the equation in action/coping behaviors still has a problem, particularly on the negative discrepancy side. In particular, the equation creates a positive feedback loop. That is, if somehow environmental states rise above one’s desires, the equation will represent the idea that the person will act to raise environmental states even more. As we just argued, this might not be unreasonable, and is certainly more reasonable than acting to lower environment states (i.e., act to make things less to a person’s liking). However, if these positive actions are effective, the environmental states will rise more, creating an even larger negative discrepancy, which makes one feel even better, but act even harder. If we were to finish the model and run the simulation one will see this leads to rapidly escalating behaviors and states. This is just the type of problem a dynamic model can reveal. Fortunately, we can fix this. Specifically, if we replace “–discrepancy/2” with “ediscrepancy” we get a positive output from the action/coping behavior function, but one that rapidly dissipates to a very small number as the negative discrepancy grows. This is one of the nice properties of the exponential function that make it a popular choice for computational and mathematical modeling (e.g., Tversky & Kahneman, 1992). That is, the equation in action/coping behavior should read like this:

Notice that we added + 1 to discrepancies when the conditional is true. That is because the exponential result will be 1 when discrepancies are 0. Adding 1 to positive discrepancies will create a smooth transition and is consistent with the idea that one will act to improve conditions (i.e., environmental states) beyond one’s desired states (i.e., is consistent with a soft maximum desire).

However, a close reading of Edwards (1992) reveals that the arrow from discrepancy to coping refers to an anticipatory effect, which we are not attempting to model. There is also an arrow from well-being to coping that serves as a repair function according to Edwards’s theory (i.e., after well-being has been damaged). This is consistent with numerous psychological models that suggest that affect (e.g., job satisfaction) is a mediator between discrepancies and action (e.g., Bandura, 1986). Yet, we just argued that when on the negative discrepancy side, the effect of discrepancies changes sign in terms of its effects on well-being (or job satisfaction), but not in terms of its effect on action. This creates a problem for the mediator conceptualization of affect. Our solution is to model action as a responsive function of discrepancy directly, not through well-being. There may be other ways of addressing this issue, but our point is that computational modeling makes it clear that a conceptual problem might exist that verbal theories did not reveal. Indeed, we did not anticipate this particular issue would arise when we selected this problem for this tutorial. It was in the process of building the model that made it clear, and we have yet to run the model!

Returning to the model, there is only one more variable/function to resolve before we can run it: Environmental States. Notice that this variable is another dynamic variable; hence it is capitalized. Again, this represents the idea that things do not changed unless acted on. One thing that might change the level of the environmental states is an individual’s actions/coping behaviors, though not instantaneously. This is why we added “environmental responsiveness” to the model. Specifically, the environment might be more or less responsive to action on states in the environment. For example, one might attempt to cope with a stressor and get nowhere at one time, while at other times one makes progress at reducing the stressor. Environmental responsiveness can represent those conditions. This gives us the following equation:

Because this is an integral function, it needs an initial state. We start with 0, which means Environmental States begins at the level desired for them (also zero). Now, if you have been following closely in VensimPLE®, your model should be ready to run. If so, you have successfully built a computational model (see https://sites.google.com/site/motivationmodeling/home if you have problems).

sec.title: Step 4: Evaluating the Model
sec.p: Evaluating models is a multistep process similar to evaluating theories. The first step, though, is unique to computational models. It involves running simulations and assessing the results. We begin discussing this process within our example.

sec.title: Simulating the model
sec.p: A question one should ask at this point is what should happen. That is, what would one expect, or what does one think the literature has to say, a unit (i.e., person) would do and feel in the context being modeled? There are several results to inspect. If using VensimPLE®, you will find that you can easily access graphs to see how each variable changes (or does not change) over the simulated time, like that shown in Figure 3. That figure shows that discrepancies and behavior go down (i.e., negatively relate to time), whereas Environmental States, perceptions, and Well-Being go up over time. All the variables appear to be approaching asymptotes except Well-Being, which rises slowly at first, but eventually to a faster, steady increase. On one level, these results are promising. Simulations can give errors because variables reach impossible levels. That does not appear to be happening here. Unfortunately, these results seem difficult to justify. That is, it seems unlikely that an individual’s well-being (or job satisfaction) will simply increase over time when the environment starts at one’s desired state.

caption.p: Endogenous variables trajectories from original simulation

sec.p: To understand why the model is doing this, notice the range of values each variable assumes over the time frame simulated. In the case of Environmental States and perceptions, they are rising from zero to positive values; discrepancies is moving from zero to negative values, Well-Being is rising from 7 to just under 100, and actions/coping is moving from one to zero. What these graphs tell us is that the individual acts to make the environment better even though it is at the desired level. Because the actions improve the environmental state, a negative discrepancy is created. Actions continue, though they drop off gradually until the actions have moved the state of the environment to about one unit. Because the resulting state creates a negative discrepancy, well-being continues to rise. This is the nature of dynamic variables. The input into the variable may be constant, but unless it is zero, the variable will change at the rate of the input.

To get a better handle on the problem, and a better understanding of how to assess models, change the initial state of the Environmental States to –7, and rerun the model. This process of changing the values of the parameters and observing the results is called sensitivity analysis (Davis et al., 2007). It is a primary method for evaluating models. In this case, it continues to show the problem that well-being does not seem to exhibit the stability it exhibits in humans. This problem is especially obvious if environmental responsiveness is changed to 0at the 20th time step (about the time the Environmental States gets to the desired level for the individual). If one runs a simulation under this condition they will find that Well-Being/Job Satisfaction, which was dropping while Environmental States was low, remains low despite the fact that Environmental States is at their desired level. Again, this does not seem right.

There might be several ways to address this issue mathematically, but we want something that is theoretically justifiable. In the case of emotions and affect, a dynamic theory exists that is called opponent process theory (Landy, 1978). Opponent process theory argues that as soon as an emotion is experienced, counterforces engage to counter act it. These are not coping behaviors as represented in our model, but negative feedback processes internal to the individual. Negative feedback loops, like the one in our model, have three components: (1) a referent or desired state, (2) a measure of the current state, and (3) a factor that determines the effect of the discrepancy between the current and desired state. In the case of opponent process, we call the referent equilibrium level. Because Well-Being/Job Satisfaction is a dynamic variable, it can be its own current state measure. Finally, we can add a constant called opponent process rate to represent the discrepancy effect factor. Add these two variables and connect them to Well-Being/Job Satisfaction.

To add the opponent process concept to the equation affecting Well-Being/Job Satisfaction, you need to add the math representing the negative feedback loop. This is simply equilibrium level – Well-Being/Job Satisfaction × opponent process rate. This should be added to what is already in the equation. Specifically, the equation should be
where,

Also, change the initial value (was 7) to equilibrium level. This way equilibrium level represents both the initial level and the steady state equilibrium point for well-being/job satisfaction. Now make equilibrium level equal to 7. For opponent process rate we want the rate to be less than one to represent the idea that is will take some time to restore well-being/job satisfaction; use 0.5.

Now another simulation can be run. The same conditions can be created (i.e., initial state = –7, environmental responsiveness steps from 0.1 to 0at time 20). Now the graph for Well-Being/Job Satisfaction will look more reasonable (see Figure 4). That is, well-being begun dropping from its initial equilibrium value, but then began to recover as both a function of its own opponent process and the reduction in the negative effect of the dropping discrepancy. Soon after the 20th day, well-being returned to and stayed at equilibrium without forces to disturb it.

caption.p: Endogenous variables trajectories from final simulation

sec.title: Reporting results
sec.p: The previous description represents the running of simulations and an example of sensitive analysis. Though there is a lot more to model evaluation, which we describe presently, often articles that introduce a computational model stop at this point. Part of this is because it takes a lot of space to describe the model, including the problem it addresses, the verbal theory being translated, and research evidence that informs the model. Indeed, we gave that element short shrift here given the purpose of this article. Moreover, the sensitivity analysis section of computational modeling articles can be quite extensive. Specifically, sensitivity analysis involves changing initial conditions, probability distributions for parameter values, or even the presences or absence of substructures of the model to determine the robustness of the model to initial conditions, assumptions, and the relevance of (i.e., degree that model behavior is sensitive to) parameters or substructures (Busemeyer & Diederich, 2010). For example, when presenting the model developed here, one might show the effect of removing the opponent processes substructure from the base model. The results of these sensitivity analyses might be the specification of boundaries for parameter values or distributions, changes to the model because of instabilities across reasonable initial states, or the removal of insensitive parameters (i.e., changing multipliers to one and additive terms to zero) to increase parsimony. Some of this analysis will be described in print, but most will not. For example, changes to the model to create stability where there was instability are typically shielded from the reader unless the changes have important ramifications for the theory from which the model was instantiated.

Note that one legitimate and worthy outcome of computationally modeling is to see if a theory can really work. That is, as we have said, theories come from a reasoning process that is difficult and flawed (Johnson-Laird & Yang, 2008). Computational models help us test that reasoning (Farrell & Lewandowsky, 2010). Thus, getting a model to work, even if it is a model of an existing verbal theory describing a well-known empirically demonstrated phenomenon—actually, especially in that case (Shadish, Cook, & Campbell, 2002)—is an accomplishment worth disseminating. Likewise, describing computational modeling attempts that do not lead to a workable model are important because they might represent cases where modelers have identified logical inconsistencies in the verbal theory. Indeed, we encourage attempts to operationalize theories researchers suspect would not work. Eliminating poor theories is a major element of scientific process (Meehl, 1978; Popper, 1969). Sastry (1997) provides an example of this type of contribution. Moving in the other direction, the results from sensitivity analysis of computational models can also inform theory and research where no theory existed before. Simon (1956) provided an example of this with regards the general problem of choosing among multiple paths or goals where many paths are available, 2 and Vancouver, Weinhardt, et al. (2010) did this recently for a multiple-goal problem as well.

We also want to encourage scholars to build on models that exist. For example, the model described in this tutorial has much potential for expansion. For instance, we operationalized well-being and job satisfaction as arising from the discrepancy between desires and states. This provided a generic perspective for understanding some processes that are likely involved. However, it is also likely that a great deal more can be learned by attempting to represent specific desires (e.g., just treatment) or a set of desires that might be of different types (e.g., optima, hard maxima). An examination of the informal theories on which our sample model was based is another source of ideas. Specifically, both Edwards (1992) and Hulin and Judge (2003) included constructs that affected the levels of desires. Adding factors that turn an exogenous variable in one model to an endogenous variable in a more expansive model is common (Repenning, 2003). Alternatively, one might use the current or refined representation of the individual in an agent-based modeling approach. For example, Hanisch, Hulin, and Seitz (1996) describe a model of human attitudes and behavior similar to the one described here, but with more precise specification of the behaviors (e.g., various forms of withdrawal from work behavior). They then described simulations where distributions of “humans” with varying parameters are represented in virtual organizations to examine organizational-level outcomes that emerge as the virtual humans behave over time. In another article, Seitz, Hulin, and Hanisch (2000) explore the effects of organizational and environmental variables in these virtual organizations.

Note that the types of modeling exercises previously described represent another aspect of sensitivity analysis, called experimentation (see Davis et al., 2007, footnote 7). Experimentation with computational modeling involves varying the values of parameters to (a) illustrate model behavior (i.e., have it make predictions), (b) “unpack” theoretical constructs by operationalizing theoretical multidimensionality, (c) change structural elements to test theoretical notions, or (d) add new elements to increase the scope of the model. Indeed, one of the main reasons for constructing computational models is to examine phenomena not easily amenable to manipulation in vivo (Davis et al., 2007; Harrison et al., 2007). Again, the results of these analyses are often only reported when intriguing (Davis et al., 2007). Though if they are too intriguing, the modeler might not report them; at least not right away. Though experimentation can illustrate novel predictions that everyone wants from good theory (Thomas & McClelland, 2008), it risks being too counterintuitive, making the model appear invalid. Indeed, the model may well be invalid. Thus, such predictions should be followed up empirically prior to submitting the modeling paper, if possible. That way, if the prediction is found to be inaccurate, the modeler knows he or she indeed has a problem with the model. However, if the prediction is accurate, then he or she can show this in a follow-up paper, vastly increasing the model’s value. This involves evaluating the model against data.

sec.title: Evaluating models against data
sec.p: There are various qualitative and quantitative methods for evaluating computational models against data (Busemeyer & Diederich, 2010). For example, showing that the model produces behavior consistent with the behavior the theory was meant to explain is what Taber and Timpone (1996) call postdiction (i.e., fits to existing data), and demonstrating that a theory can reproduce some finding, particularly a well-documented causal relationship, is a major role of science (Shadish et al., 2002). Typically, qualitative comparisons involve matching the pattern of behavior (usually over time) of individual behavior with the pattern exhibited by the model. One might also simulate units using different parameters related to the unit of analysis (e.g., individual difference parameters) and assess the associations they reveal between variables in the model to see if they match the associations found in existing studies. Vancouver, Tamanini, et al. (2010) used this approach to evaluate a model of feedback seeking among organizational newcomers.

Quantitative comparisons involve estimating the free parameters in the model. There are two general methods of parameter estimation: least squares estimation (LSE) and maximum likelihood estimation (MLE). Myung (2003) provides a tutorial on how to perform MLE, which is preferred because it can handle the kind of nonlinear and nonnormal data common to dynamic phenomena. LSE and MLE can also be used to create confidence intervals and test hypotheses. Perhaps more importantly, these estimation procedures provide an index of how well the models fit the observed data, just as they do with regression and SEM. How well a model fits the data is called its goodness of fit (GOF) and determines the descriptive adequacy of the model (Myung, 2000). GOF represents a comparison of models. When assessing a single computational model the alternative is a null model or, its opposite, a fully saturated model (for a quantitative with a null model, see Vancouver et al., 2005). Note that because we are talking about dynamic process models, the analyses are done on individual units. Thus, several fits or a description of their distribution will be reported if multiple participants are involved.

These model testing procedures are no different in kind than theory testing procedures generally employed. The only major difference is that with computational models one can run simulations to determine or illustrate the predictions stemming from the model. In the case of verbal theories, researchers do this as well, though they must rely on imperfect reasoning processes to infer the theory’s prediction (Johnson-Laird & Yang, 2008). However, computational models also have the potential to provide much more precise predictions if researchers can identify, and determine the level of, parameters in the models. For example, if the lags in the processes represented in the example model were known (e.g., what is the rate of opponent processes for job satisfaction) or measured (e.g., what is the responsiveness of this or that environment), then more precise trajectories could be predicted. As Edwards and Berry (2010) argue, this precision provides not only better tests of theories, but also more useful theories.

sec.title: Evaluating models against each other
sec.p: Earlier we noted that the match of model behavior (i.e., prediction/postdiction) is often compared to the match of a null or saturated model. However, comparing models of alternative theories represents the strong inference theory testing approach highly touted in the research methods literature (Leavitt, Mitchell, & Peterson, 2010; Platt, 1964). There are three variations on this theme. The first occurs in fields like learning and decision making, where computational and mathematical models have been challenged with a large set of findings that do not correspond with those models. As a result, new models are introduced by showing that they can account for more of these findings than the existing models. Unfortunately, organizational science is not a very mature field. We do not have many robust empirical findings and we have even fewer computational models. That said, one might be able to perform this kind assessment when addressing learning or decision making phenomena, both of which have received computational attention (Nutt & Wilson, 2010; Senge, 1990).

The second variation involves quantitative model assessment and GOF indices. When comparing two models, the model that fits the data the best is the more accurate model. That said, researchers need to be cautious when using GOF. More complex models (i.e., models with more free parameters) will fit the data better than less complex models. Therefore, models must be evaluated not only on their GOF, but also on their complexity and generalizability. That is, a complex model can fit a diverse set of data patterns, but generalizability is reduced because the model is fitting the random error (Pitt & Myung, 2002). This is similar to the problem of biodata instruments in selection, where weighting keys need to be cross-validated because of their tendency to be sample specific. In contrast, simple models are likely to generalize better because parameter estimates will be more stable. Given this, there are at least seven different methods available that take the complexity of a model as well as GOF into account to facilitate model comparison (Myung, 2000).

The third variation is our preferred method. Again, two or more models exist or are created; these models are simulated and reproduce a finding but differ in explanation. The article then describes a protocol or conditions, likely represented in the context element of the models, where the models make differing predictions (i.e., hypotheses). The researcher then describes the results of running participants through the protocol, or finds observable cases where the important, diagnostic conditions exist, to determine which hypothesis is supported. Again, this is the strong inference type of scenario. Unfortunately, in our field, the authors generally have to operationalize all the models examined (e.g., Hanisch et al., 1996; Vancouver & Scherbaum, 2008). A problem that this type of exercise presents is that advocates of one or more of the theories, particularly ones that lose an empirical battle, might complain that their theory is not adequately or accurately represented by the model. Although a potentially legitimate concern, the exercise is important because it brings to the forefront ambiguities in the theory as well as an incentive to formalize the theory properly. The other thing to remember is that theories that appear to be about the same phenomenon often address different issues. In these cases, the use of modeling to “pit” the models is useful because it explicitly represents the conditions in which the models are tested and might lead to integrating efforts.

Finally, we want to reiterate what this last section implies, which is that a working computational model, just like a theory that makes sense and is consistent with data, is not necessarily valid (i.e., a true representation of the processes involved in determining the phenomenon). That is, a danger one must always guard against is becoming overly enamored with a computational model just because it “works.” Models need to be continually assessed against data and against other theories/models. This can include assessing patterns of behavior that arise from the system, specific elements of a model (e.g., using reading time measures to examine predictions of working memory use; Just & Carpenter, 1992), or knowledge of the constraints a medium (e.g., speed of neural operations; Newell, 1990) places on the processes taking place in the medium. For example, opponent processes were originally theorized to occur within seconds or minutes (Solomon & Corbit, 1974). Therefore, a test of the model might include a test of the assumption that opponent processes can also occur over longer periods.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: In this article, we have argued that the phenomena organizational scholars study and the theories developed to explain the phenomena tax human cognitive capacities. Under such conditions, humans often distribute some cognitive work to the environment (e.g., Hutchins, 1995). Computational modeling is an external support mechanism developed for just that reason (i.e., to support human reasoning). Moreover, the tools for developing such models have improved substantially and have become readily available. In this article, we address a psychological chasm deterring the use of computational models more widely (i.e., the belief that computational modeling is itself too difficult) by describing the steps involved in creating and evaluating computational models. If Galileo is correct, this may increase the number of organizational scholars that can speak the language of the universe—a language that should not only facilitate clear communication among scholars, but also greatly improve the quality of dynamic theories of complex systems, which are just the sort of systems organizational scholars study.

ack.title: Recommended Readings
ack.p: Lewandowsky, S., & Farrell, S. (2011). Computational modeling in cognition: Principles and practices. Thousand Oaks, CA: Sage. A text on creating and evaluation computational models for cognitive contexts.
Busemeyer, J. R., & Diederich, A. (2010). Cognitive modeling. Los Angeles, CA: Sage. A text on evaluation methods for computational models.

Sun, R. (Ed.). (2008). The Cambridge handbook of computational psychology. New York, NY: Cambridge University Press. An edited volume of computational architectures and applications of computational approaches.
Taber, C. S., & Timpone, R. J. (1996). Computational modeling. Thousand Oaks, CA: Sage. A primer for computational modeling.

ack.title: Acknowledgments
ack.p: We thank Amanda R. Cameron for creating the website that contains supplemental material. We also thank Michael A. Warren, Jason L. Harman, Xiaofel Li, and Justin D. Purl for helpful comments on an earlier version of this article.

fn.label: Declaration of Conflicting Interests
fn.p: The author(s) declared no potential conflicts of interest with respect to the research, authorship, and/or publication of this article.

fn.label: Funding
fn.p: The author(s) disclosed receipt of the following financial support for the research, authorship, and/or publication of this article: This work is supported by NSF (Grant #0851764), with funding from the American Recovery and Reinvestment Act of 2009.

For most academic purposes, VensimPLE® is all one needs to construct and test models. However, the more advanced versions, which use the same interface, allow users to obtain model parameter estimates or conducting Monte Carlo simulations within the software. A full discussion of the differences between the software can be found at the vendor’s website. Everything done in the current tutorial can be done with the free version.
We thank an anonymous reviewer for pointing out this example.
